question: 40 year old male with newly diagnosed moderate UC and articular extraintestinal manifestations
gt_reason: IFX is ideal choice as biologically naïve with EIM.

System: 
You are a physician assistant giving advice on treatment for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis (UC).
Make reference to the CONTEXT given to assess the scenario.
If the answer cannot be inferred from CONTEXT, return "NO ANSWER", don't try to make up an answer.
=================================
TASK: ANALYSE the given patient profile based on given query based on one of the following criteria:
- Whether treated patient is new patient or patient under maintenance
- Prior response to Infliximab
- Prior failure to Anti-TNF agents
- Prior failure to Vedolizumab
- Age
- Pregnancy
- Extraintestinale manifestations
- Pouchitis

FINALLY RETURN up to 2 TOP choices of biological drugs given patient profile and context. Explain the PROS and CONS of the 2 choices.
If answer cannot be derived from context, RETURN "NO ANSWER" and explain reason.
=================================
OUTPUT INSTRUCTIONS:
Output your answer as a list of JSON objects with keys: drug_name, advantages, disadvantages.
=================================
CONTEXT:
summaries
=================================

Human: PATIENT PROFILE: question
pro1: Vedolizumab is an anti-integrin antibody that has shown efficacy in treating moderate to severe UC. It is gut-selective, which means it specifically targets the gut immune response, potentially reducing systemic side effects.
cons1: However, due to its gut-selective nature, it may not be as effective in managing extraintestinal manifestations such as articular symptoms. Additionally, some patients may experience infusion reactions.
pro2: Infliximab is a TNF-alpha inhibitor that has been shown to be effective in treating moderate to severe UC. It can also help manage extraintestinal manifestations, including articular symptoms, due to its systemic effects.
cons2: However, some patients may develop antibodies to infliximab, leading to a loss of response over time. Infusion reactions and increased risk of infections are also potential side effects.

INTRODUCTION 
  Ulcerative colitis (UC) is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the bowel that causes 
continuous mucosal inflammation commencing in the rectum and extending proximally for a 
variable extent.[1] It is estimated that UC affects 2.5 million people in Europe,[2] and the 
disease follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent flares of disease activity, 
some of which may be moderate to severe. Management of these is medical, for the most 
part, with surgery reserved for patients with refractory disease. Although 5-aminosalicylates 
(5-ASAs) are efficacious for mild to moderate disease activity,[3-6] more severe flares are 
usually treated with corticosteroids.[7] However, these have potentially serious adverse 
effects and a substantial proportion of patients may become either dependent on them to 
maintain remission,[8] or refractory to them.[9] As a result, over the last 20 years novel

title: Efficacy of biological therapies and small molecules in moderate to severe ulcerative colitis: systematic review and network meta-analysis

text: Burr et al. 
 
5 of 45 
STUDY HIGHLIGHTS 
 
What is already known about this subject 
• Ulcerative colitis (UC) follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent 
flares of disease activity, some of which may be moderate to severe. 
• These are usually treated with corticosteroids, which have potentially serious adverse 
effects, so biological therapies and small molecules have been developed and licensed 
for this indication.  
• Although previous network meta-analyses have compared their efficacy and safety, 
this is a rapidly moving field, and there are already several newer drugs that have 
shown efficacy in phase III clinical trials that were not considered in these. 
 
What are the new findings 
• In terms of clinical remission and clinical response, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked 
first in all patients, in patients previously exposed to anti-tumour necrosis factor 
(TNF)-α therapies, and in patients naïve to these drugs.

therapies. 
Our results confirm that all available drugs, other than adalimumab 160/160mg, 
adalimumab 80/40mg, and filgotinib 100mg o.d. were more efficacious than placebo for the 
treatment of moderate to severe UC, across all endpoints studied at 6 to 14 weeks. All drugs 
were safe and well-tolerated, with no significant increase in serious adverse events or adverse 
events leading to withdrawal over the rates seen in the placebo arms, although the RR of
source9:
title: Efficacy of biological therapies and small molecules in moderate to severe ulcerative colitis: systematic review and network meta-analysis

filename: gutjnl-2021-326390R2 CLEAN.pdf

page: 27

text: Burr et al. 
 
27 of 45 
DISCUSSION 
We conducted a contemporaneous systematic review and network meta-analysis of 
biological therapies and small molecules for moderate to severely active UC. This has 
incorporated data from 28 RCTs and over 12,500 patients. Overall, in terms of clinical 
remission and clinical response at 6 to 14 weeks, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked first in all 
patients, in patients previously exposed to anti-TNF-α therapies, and in patients naïve to these 
drugs. In terms of endoscopic improvement infliximab 10mg/kg ranked first, followed by 
upadacitinib 45mg o.d., and infliximab 5mg/kg. However, again upadacitinib 45mg o.d. 
ranked first in patients previously exposed to anti-TNF-α therapies, and in patients who were 
anti-TNF-α naïve. In terms of safety, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked last for total number of 
adverse events, and ustekinumab 130mg first. However, none of the drugs studied were more

Human: PATIENT PROFILE: question
pro1: Upadacitinib has been found to be potentially more efficacious for moderate to severely active UC than existing licensed therapies. It has been ranked first in terms of clinical remission and clinical response at 6 to 14 weeks, in patients previously exposed to anti-TNF-α therapies, and in patients naïve to these drugs. It is also ranked first in terms of endoscopic improvement in patients previously exposed to anti-TNF-α therapies, and in patients who were anti-TNF-α naïve.
cons1: Upadacitinib ranked last for total number of adverse events, indicating a higher risk of side effects. The safety profile of this drug in elderly patients is not specifically mentioned in the context.
pro2: Infliximab has been found to be effective in terms of endoscopic improvement, ranking first among all drugs. It is a biologic therapy that has been used for over 20 years, indicating a well-established safety and efficacy profile.
cons2: The safety and efficacy of Infliximab in elderly patients is not specifically mentioned in the context. As a biologic, it may have limitations including primary nonresponse, secondary loss of response, immunogenicity, and parenteral administration.

Human: PATIENT PROFILE: question
pro1: Ustekinumab has been ranked highest in patients with prior exposure to TNF antagonists, like infliximab, for induction of remission and endoscopic improvement. It is a good option for patients who have not responded well to anti-TNF agents.
cons1: The exact efficacy of ustekinumab in comparison to other drugs is not fully established due to lack of direct comparison trials. Side effects can include infections, allergic reactions, and potential risk of malignancies.
pro2: Tofacitinib is also ranked highly in patients with prior exposure to TNF antagonists for induction of remission and endoscopic improvement. It is a small molecule drug and not a biologic, which may have different side effect profiles beneficial for some patients.
cons2: Tofacitinib can have side effects including serious infections, increased cholesterol levels, increased risk of heart problems, and potential risk of cancer. It is also not recommended for patients with severe liver problems.

Introduction 
Ulcerative colitis is a chronic, idiopathic, potentially 
disabling condition that is clinically characterised 
by bloody diarrhoea, abdominal pain, and tenesmus.1 
Ulcerative colitis most commonly presents during the 
third and fifth decades of life, and is associated with an 
impaired health-related quality of life and considerable 
economic burden.2,3
Nearly 20 years ago, the advent of anti-tumour necrosis 
factor biologics (eg, infliximab, adalimumab, and 
golimumab) revolutionised therapeutics for ulcerative 
colitis, enabling better disease control in terms of 
increasing the rates of mucosal healing, deep remission, 
and corticosteroid-free remission, and improving quality 
of life. Biologics with other targets were later approved 
for the treatment of moderate-to-severe ulcerative colitis,

tofacitinib ranked highest in patients previously exposed to biologics.[23] This later network 
meta-analysis included 14 induction of remission trials, recruiting almost 5500 patients, 
although the Japanese trial of infliximab versus placebo in 208 patients reported by 
Kobayashi et al. was not included.[42] In contrast to these previous network meta-analyses, 
our results provide hope that some novel drugs, which are likely to come to market soon, are 
potentially more efficacious for moderate to severely active UC than existing licensed 
therapies. 
Our results confirm that all available drugs, other than adalimumab 160/160mg,

INTRODUCTION 
  Ulcerative colitis (UC) is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the bowel that causes 
continuous mucosal inflammation commencing in the rectum and extending proximally for a 
variable extent.[1] It is estimated that UC affects 2.5 million people in Europe,[2] and the 
disease follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent flares of disease activity, 
some of which may be moderate to severe. Management of these is medical, for the most 
part, with surgery reserved for patients with refractory disease. Although 5-aminosalicylates 
(5-ASAs) are efficacious for mild to moderate disease activity,[3-6] more severe flares are 
usually treated with corticosteroids.[7] However, these have potentially serious adverse 
effects and a substantial proportion of patients may become either dependent on them to 
maintain remission,[8] or refractory to them.[9] As a result, over the last 20 years novel
source9:
title: First- and Second-Line Pharmacotherapies for Patients With Moderate to Severely Active Ulcerative Colitis: An Updated Network Meta-Analysis

filename: PIIS1542356520300446.pdf

text: What You Need to Know
Background
A systematic review and network meta-analysis is
needed to compare efﬁcacy and safety of ﬁrst-line
(biologic-naïve) and second-line (prior exposure to
tumor necrosis factor [TNF] antagonists) agents for
treatment of moderate to severely active ulcerative
colitis.
Findings
Inﬂiximab was ranked highest in biologic-naïve pa-
tients, and ustekinumab and tofacitinib were ranked
highest in patients with prior exposure to TNF an-
tagonists, for induction of remission and endoscopic
improvement. More trials of direct comparisons are
needed to inform clinical decision-making with
greater conﬁdence.
Implications for patient care
Patients with moderate to severely active ulcerative
colitis should receive inﬂiximab or vedolizumab as
ﬁrst-line therapy, or ustekinumab or tofacitinib if
they have prior exposure to TNF antagonists.

Human: PATIENT PROFILE: question
pro1: Vedolizumab is an anti-integrin antibody that has shown efficacy in treating moderate to severe UC. It is generally well-tolerated and has a good safety profile. It is also a good option for patients who are biologic-naïve, as it does not require prior exposure to other biological therapies.
cons1: The effectiveness of Vedolizumab may vary among individuals. It may take several weeks to months for the full effects to be seen. Side effects can include headache, joint pain, nausea, and fatigue. Serious side effects can include infections and liver problems.
pro2: Ustekinumab is an anti-interleukin-12/23 antibody that has shown efficacy in treating moderate to severe UC. It is generally well-tolerated and has a good safety profile. It can be used in patients who are biologic-naïve.
cons2: The effectiveness of Ustekinumab may vary among individuals. It may take several weeks to months for the full effects to be seen. Side effects can include upper respiratory infections, headache, and fatigue. Serious side effects can include serious infections, cancer, and heart failure.

text: Burr et al.

STUDY HIGHLIGHTS 
 
What is already known about this subject 
• Ulcerative colitis (UC) follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent 
flares of disease activity, some of which may be moderate to severe. 
• These are usually treated with corticosteroids, which have potentially serious adverse 
effects, so biological therapies and small molecules have been developed and licensed 
for this indication.  
• Although previous network meta-analyses have compared their efficacy and safety, 
this is a rapidly moving field, and there are already several newer drugs that have 
shown efficacy in phase III clinical trials that were not considered in these. 
 
What are the new findings 
• In terms of clinical remission and clinical response, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked 
first in all patients, in patients previously exposed to anti-tumour necrosis factor 
(TNF)-α therapies, and in patients naïve to these drugs.

Human: PATIENT PROFILE: question
pro1: Ustekinumab is a good choice for this patient as it has been shown to be effective in treating both UC and psoriasis, which the patient has. It is also safe and well-tolerated.
cons1: The main disadvantage of Ustekinumab is that it may not be as efficacious as some other therapies for UC, such as upadacitinib. It also requires parenteral administration.
pro2: Upadacitinib has been shown to be highly efficacious in treating moderate to severe UC, even in patients who are new to treatment or have had prior exposure to anti-TNF-α therapies. It is also orally administered, which may be more convenient for the patient.
cons2: The main disadvantage of upadacitinib is that it has not been specifically indicated for the treatment of psoriasis. Additionally, it ranked last in terms of total number of adverse events in a study, suggesting it may have a higher risk of side effects.

text: Burr et al. 
 
27 of 45 
DISCUSSION 
We conducted a contemporaneous systematic review and network meta-analysis of 
biological therapies and small molecules for moderate to severely active UC. This has 
incorporated data from 28 RCTs and over 12,500 patients. Overall, in terms of clinical 
remission and clinical response at 6 to 14 weeks, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked first in all 
patients, in patients previously exposed to anti-TNF-α therapies, and in patients naïve to these 
drugs. In terms of endoscopic improvement infliximab 10mg/kg ranked first, followed by 
upadacitinib 45mg o.d., and infliximab 5mg/kg. However, again upadacitinib 45mg o.d. 
ranked first in patients previously exposed to anti-TNF-α therapies, and in patients who were 
anti-TNF-α naïve. In terms of safety, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked last for total number of 
adverse events, and ustekinumab 130mg first. However, none of the drugs studied were more

The advanced therapeutic armamentarium for adults 
with moderately to severely active UC is rapidly evolving. 
For over 20 years, biologics targeting specific inflamma-
tory pathways have been the mainstay, beginning with those 
targeting tumor necrosis alpha (TNFi; eg, infliximab [INF], 
adalimumab [ADA], and golimumab [GOL]) followed by 
biologics with other modes of action (eg, vedolizumab [VED] 
and ustekinumab [UST]). However, treatment limitations for 
moderately to severely active UC remain, including primary 
nonresponse, secondary loss of response, immunogenicity, and 
parenteral administration.2 To overcome these limitations, 
there has been increasing interest in small molecule drugs 
(SMDs), which can be orally administered and lack immu-
nogenicity.3 Of particular interest are SMDs that inhibit the

text: semi-systematic review suggest that IBD cutaneous lesions may respond
to the newer IBD drugs. This is the case for ustekinumab and less
frequently for vedolizumab (Phillips et al., 2020; Ben Abdallah et al.,
2021). Uveitis also appears to respond to anti-TNF agents (Leal et al.,

(Christensen et al., 2018; Lynch et al., 2020).
Fistula development affects up to 50% of CD patients over 20 years of
disease course. Half of these patients experience perianal ﬁstula (Rub-
bino et al., 2021). After surgical drainage of pelvic sepsis, medical ther-
apy may be undertaken. Best results so far are obtained with anti-TNF
agents. Among them, only inﬂiximab has been evaluated in a large,
dedicated placebo-randomized trial. Out of 366 patients who received
induction with 5 mg/kg inﬂiximab at Week 0, 2 and 6, 195 responders

Human: PATIENT PROFILE: question
pro1: Vedolizumab is a gut-selective immunosuppressant, meaning it specifically targets the gut and has less systemic side effects. It is generally well-tolerated and has been shown to be effective in treating moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It is also considered safe for use during pregnancy.
cons1: Vedolizumab may take several weeks to start working, which may not be ideal for patients with severe symptoms. It also requires intravenous administration, which can be inconvenient. There is also a risk of infusion reactions.
pro2: TNFi such as infliximab and adalimumab have been shown to be effective in treating moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. They can induce and maintain remission, and improve quality of life. Some TNFi are also considered safe for use during pregnancy.
cons2: TNFi can have systemic side effects, including increased risk of infections. They can also cause allergic reactions. Some patients may develop antibodies to these drugs, making them less effective over time.

The International Organization for the Study of Inﬂam-
matory Bowel Disease and the American Gastroenterological
Association (AGA) provide a framework for categorization of
CD and UC severity into mild-, moderate-, and high-risk
groups based on phenotype and other characteristics.59,60
In CD, the presence of large or deep mucosal lesions on
endoscopy or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), history of
a ﬁstula, abscess, or intestinal resection are predictors of
worse outcomes.59,60 In a prospective population-based
inception cohort of 213 patients with CD, penetrating
behavior was associated with a higher risk of progression to
perianal disease (HR, 5.65; 95% CI, 2.65–12.03) and was a
risk factor for resection (HR, 3.92; 95% CI, 1.86–8.67) and
hospitalization (HR, 1.01; 95% CI, 1.00–1.01).16 Ileal and
upper gastrointestinal disease location and extensive dis-
ease are also markers of severe disease.61 Cigarette smoking

with recently diagnosed CD, all of whom underwent MRI

Human: PATIENT PROFILE: question
pro1: Infliximab is a TNF-alpha inhibitor that has been shown to be effective in controlling the symptoms of moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It can also be beneficial for patients with ankylosing spondylitis, a type of arthritis that affects the spine.
cons1: Infliximab can have side effects including infections, allergic reactions, and liver damage. It may also not be suitable for patients who have had a prior failure to Anti-TNF agents.
pro2: Upadacitinib has been ranked first in terms of clinical remission and response in all patients, including those previously exposed to anti-TNF-alpha therapies and those naive to these drugs. This suggests it could be a good option for this patient.
cons2: Upadacitinib is a newer drug and its long-term safety profile is not as well established as some other treatments. It may also have side effects including infections, changes in blood counts, and liver problems.

text: Burr et al. 
 
5 of 45 
STUDY HIGHLIGHTS 
 
What is already known about this subject 
• Ulcerative colitis (UC) follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent 
flares of disease activity, some of which may be moderate to severe. 
• These are usually treated with corticosteroids, which have potentially serious adverse 
effects, so biological therapies and small molecules have been developed and licensed 
for this indication.  
• Although previous network meta-analyses have compared their efficacy and safety, 
this is a rapidly moving field, and there are already several newer drugs that have 
shown efficacy in phase III clinical trials that were not considered in these. 
 
What are the new findings 
• In terms of clinical remission and clinical response, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked 
first in all patients, in patients previously exposed to anti-tumour necrosis factor 
(TNF)-α therapies, and in patients naïve to these drugs.

Human: PATIENT PROFILE: question
pro1: Infliximab is a TNF antagonist that has revolutionized therapeutics for ulcerative colitis, enabling better disease control in terms of increasing the rates of mucosal healing, deep remission, and corticosteroid-free remission, and improving quality of life.
cons1: Infliximab has several limitations, including limited efficacy, primary non-response, secondary loss of response, and immunogenicity. It may not be effective if the patient has previously failed to respond to other TNF antagonists.
pro2: Ustekinumab is an anti-IL-12/IL-23 antibody that may be effective in patients who have failed treatment with vedolizumab. It may have a mechanistic potential in late disease stages when an expansion of Th1 and Th17 cells may have occurred.
cons2: The efficacy of ustekinumab in ulcerative colitis is not as well established as other biologics. It may not be as effective as other treatments in inducing remission.

by bloody diarrhoea, abdominal pain, and tenesmus.1 
Ulcerative colitis most commonly presents during the 
third and fifth decades of life, and is associated with an 
impaired health-related quality of life and considerable 
economic burden.2,3
Nearly 20 years ago, the advent of anti-tumour necrosis 
factor biologics (eg, infliximab, adalimumab, and 
golimumab) revolutionised therapeutics for ulcerative 
colitis, enabling better disease control in terms of 
increasing the rates of mucosal healing, deep remission, 
and corticosteroid-free remission, and improving quality 
of life. Biologics with other targets were later approved 
for the treatment of moderate-to-severe ulcerative colitis,

text: control with vedolizumab. Other factors are involved in informed shared 
decision-making — comorbid conditions, speed of onset of action and 
a patient’s values and preferences, such as the mode of administration, 
cost and access. In most jurisdictions, cost considerations upend these 
discussions, with a strong preference for using biosimilars for TNF antag-
onists and conventional immunosuppressive agents like thiopurines 
and methotrexate in resource-limited settings (Fig. 1).
Similar to Crohn’s disease, there is a paucity of head-to-head clini-
cal trials of advanced immunosuppressive therapies in patients with 
moderate-to-severe ulcerative colitis. Integrating data from the VAR-
SITY trial comparing vedolizumab versus adalimumab (Supplementary 
Table 1) with data from phase II and III trials of approved therapies, 
network meta-analyses suggest that upadacitinib, infliximab and ved-
olizumab are probably the most efficacious therapies for induction
source4:
title: Efficacy of biological therapies and small molecules in moderate to severe ulcerative colitis: systematic review and network meta-analysis

filename: gutjnl-2021-326390R2 CLEAN.pdf

page: 5

text: Burr et al. 
 
5 of 45 
STUDY HIGHLIGHTS 
 
What is already known about this subject 
• Ulcerative colitis (UC) follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent 
flares of disease activity, some of which may be moderate to severe. 
• These are usually treated with corticosteroids, which have potentially serious adverse 
effects, so biological therapies and small molecules have been developed and licensed 
for this indication.  
• Although previous network meta-analyses have compared their efficacy and safety, 
this is a rapidly moving field, and there are already several newer drugs that have 
shown efficacy in phase III clinical trials that were not considered in these. 
 
What are the new findings 
• In terms of clinical remission and clinical response, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked 
first in all patients, in patients previously exposed to anti-tumour necrosis factor 
(TNF)-α therapies, and in patients naïve to these drugs.
source5:
title: First- and Second-Line Pharmacotherapies for Patients With Moderate to Severely Active Ulcerative Colitis: An Updated Network Meta-Analysis

filename: PIIS1542356520300446.pdf

page: 0

text: (prior exposure to tumor necrosis factor [TNF] antagonists) agents for treatment of moder-
ate to severely active ulcerative colitis in a systematic review and network meta-analysis.
METHODS:
We searched publication databases through September 30, 2019, for randomized trials of
adults with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis treated with TNF antagonists, vedolizumab,
tofacitinib, or ustekinumab, as ﬁrst-line or second-line agents, compared with placebo or
another active agent. Efﬁcacy outcomes were induction and maintenance of remission and
endoscopic improvement; safety outcomes were serious adverse events and infections. We
performed a ﬁxed-effects network meta-analysis using the frequentist approach, and calculated
odds ratios (ORs) and 95% CI values. Agents were ranked using surface under the cumulative
ranking (SUCRA) probabilities. Overall quality of evidence was rated using GRADE (Grading of
Recommendations, Assessment, Development and Evaluation).
RESULTS:

kinase inhibitors (tofacitinib, filgotinib, or upadacitinib) or sphingosine-1-phosphate receptor 
modulators (ozanimod)) at the doses taken through into testing in phase III clinical trials. 
Studies had to recruit ambulatory adults (≥18 years) with moderate to severely active UC 
(Supplementary Table 1), and compared biological therapies or small molecules with 
placebo, or with each other. We required a minimum follow-up duration of 6 weeks.  
Two investigators (NEB and ACF) conducted independent literature searches. We 
identified studies on UC with the terms: inflammatory bowel disease, colitis, or ulcerative

text: multicenter retrospective study reported the outcome of patients with
late CD who had failed treatment with one anti-TNF agent and either
vedolizumab or ustekinumab. After 48 weeks on a third line of biologic
therapy the remission rate was 30.7% whereas the surgery rate was
23.5% (Kassouri et al., 2020).
There is a mechanistic role for anti-IL 23 agents in TNF refractory IBD
patients. During anti TNF treatment, in non-responders compared to re-
sponders, there is upregulation of apoptosis resistant IL23p19, IL23R,
and IL17 A as demonstrated by studies using immunophenotyping of T
cells. (Bek et al., 2016; Schmitt et al., 2019). This phenomenon suggests
that ustekinumab (as IL-12/IL-23 inhibitor) and other IL-23 inhibitor
agents may have a mechanistic potential in late CD (Eftychi et al., 2019)
when an expansion of Th1 and Th17 cells (Veny et al., 2010) may have
occurred.

[{"drug_name": "Vedolizumab", "advantages": "Vedolizumab is a gut-selective immunosuppressant, meaning it specifically targets the gut and has less systemic side effects. This could be beneficial for a patient with multiple sclerosis, as it reduces the risk of exacerbating neurological symptoms. It has been shown to be effective in inducing and maintaining remission in moderate to severe ulcerative colitis.", "disadvantages": "Vedolizumab may take longer to show effects compared to other treatments. It is administered via infusion, which may be less convenient for some patients. Side effects can include headache, joint pain, nausea, and fever."}, 

{"drug_name": "Ustekinumab", "advantages": "Ustekinumab is an interleukin inhibitor that has been shown to be effective in treating moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It has also been used in the treatment of other autoimmune diseases, including multiple sclerosis, suggesting it may have a dual benefit for this patient.", "disadvantages": "Ustekinumab requires initial intravenous administration, followed by subcutaneous injections, which may be less convenient for some patients. Potential side effects include upper respiratory infections, fatigue, and headache. There is also a risk of serious infections and malignancies with ustekinumab use."}]
pro1: Vedolizumab is a gut-selective immunosuppressant, meaning it specifically targets the gut and has less systemic side effects. This could be beneficial for a patient with multiple sclerosis, as it reduces the risk of exacerbating neurological symptoms. It has been shown to be effective in inducing and maintaining remission in moderate to severe ulcerative colitis.
cons1: Vedolizumab may take longer to show effects compared to other treatments. It is administered via infusion, which may be less convenient for some patients. Side effects can include headache, joint pain, nausea, and fever.
pro2: Ustekinumab is an interleukin inhibitor that has been shown to be effective in treating moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It has also been used in the treatment of other autoimmune diseases, including multiple sclerosis, suggesting it may have a dual benefit for this patient.
cons2: Ustekinumab requires initial intravenous administration, followed by subcutaneous injections, which may be less convenient for some patients. Potential side effects include upper respiratory infections, fatigue, and headache. There is also a risk of serious infections and malignancies with ustekinumab use.

Human: PATIENT PROFILE: question
pro1: Vedolizumab is a gut-selective immunosuppressant, meaning it specifically targets the gut and has less systemic side effects. It is generally well tolerated and has been shown to be effective in inducing and maintaining remission in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It does not have known associations with increased risk of malignancies.
cons1: Vedolizumab may take longer to work compared to other biologics. It is administered via intravenous infusion, which may be inconvenient for some patients. Some patients may also develop antibodies to vedolizumab, reducing its effectiveness.
pro2: Ustekinumab is an IL-12 and IL-23 inhibitor that has been shown to be effective in treating moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It is administered via subcutaneous injection, which can be done at home. It has a good safety profile and is not associated with an increased risk of malignancies.
cons2: Ustekinumab may not be as effective as other biologics in inducing remission. It may also take longer to work. Some patients may develop antibodies to ustekinumab, reducing its effectiveness.

INTRODUCTION 
  Ulcerative colitis (UC) is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the bowel that causes 
continuous mucosal inflammation commencing in the rectum and extending proximally for a 
variable extent.[1] It is estimated that UC affects 2.5 million people in Europe,[2] and the 
disease follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent flares of disease activity, 
some of which may be moderate to severe. Management of these is medical, for the most 
part, with surgery reserved for patients with refractory disease. Although 5-aminosalicylates 
(5-ASAs) are efficacious for mild to moderate disease activity,[3-6] more severe flares are 
usually treated with corticosteroids.[7] However, these have potentially serious adverse 
effects and a substantial proportion of patients may become either dependent on them to 
maintain remission,[8] or refractory to them.[9] As a result, over the last 20 years novel

increasing the rates of mucosal healing, deep remission,

of life. Biologics with other targets were later approved

text: Burr et al. 
 
5 of 45 
STUDY HIGHLIGHTS 
 
What is already known about this subject 
• Ulcerative colitis (UC) follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent 
flares of disease activity, some of which may be moderate to severe. 
• These are usually treated with corticosteroids, which have potentially serious adverse 
effects, so biological therapies and small molecules have been developed and licensed 
for this indication.  
• Although previous network meta-analyses have compared their efficacy and safety, 
this is a rapidly moving field, and there are already several newer drugs that have 
shown efficacy in phase III clinical trials that were not considered in these. 
 
What are the new findings 
• In terms of clinical remission and clinical response, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked 
first in all patients, in patients previously exposed to anti-tumour necrosis factor 
(TNF)-α therapies, and in patients naïve to these drugs.

pro1: Vedolizumab has been shown to be effective for long-term maintenance of clinical remission in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It has also been ranked as the safest drug in terms of adverse events and serious adverse events.
cons1: While Vedolizumab is generally well-tolerated, potential side effects can include headache, joint pain, nausea, or common cold symptoms. There is also a risk of serious infections.
pro2: Infliximab has been found to be effective in the maintenance of clinical remission and endoscopic improvement in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It is also ranked highly for induction of remission and endoscopic improvement.
cons2: Infliximab can have potential side effects including infections, infusion reactions, and potential development of antibodies to the drug which can decrease its effectiveness over time.

title: Efficacy and safety of biologics and small molecule drugs for patients with moderate-to-severe ulcerative colitis: a systematic review and network meta-analysis

page: 0

text: molecule drugs as induction or maintenance therapies for patients with moderate-to-severe ulcerative colitis were 
included. Phase 2 RCTs were excluded because of their small sample sizes and inclusion of doses not further explored 
in phase 3 RCTs. Summary data from intention-to-treat analyses were extracted from included reports by JSL and PAO. 
The primary outcome was the induction of clinical remission. A network meta-analysis was done under the frequentist 
framework, obtaining pairwise odds ratios (ORs) and 95% CIs. The surface under the cumulative ranking (SUCRA) 
was used to rank the included agents for each outcome. Higher SUCRA scores correlate with better efficacy, whereas 
lower SUCRA scores correlate with better safety. Maintenance data on efficacy for treat-straight-through and 
randomised responder trials are also presented. This study is registered with PROSPERO, CRD42021225329.

CONCLUSIONS:
In a systematic review and network meta-analysis, we found inﬂiximab to be ranked highest in
biologic-naïve patients, and ustekinumab and tofacitinib were ranked highest in patients with
prior exposure to TNF antagonists, for induction of remission and endoscopic improvement in
patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. More trials of direct comparisons are
needed to inform clinical decision making with greater conﬁdence.
Keywords: GRADE; Pharmacotherapy; Inﬂammatory Bowel Disease; UC; Comparative Efﬁcacy.

lcerative colitis affects 1 in 200 to 1 in 400 people

Discussion 
We reviewed available efficacy and safety data from RCTs 
of biologics and small molecule drugs (approved or in a 
late stage of development) for induction and maintenance 
treatment of patients with moderate-to-severe ulcerative 
colitis. All small molecule drugs and approved biologics, 
except filgotinib 100 mg, were significantly better than 
placebo in terms of inducing clinical remission and 
endoscopic improvement. A novel finding of this study 
was that upadacitinib ranked highest for the induction of 
clinical remission and endoscopic improvement, and 
was notably superior for these outcomes to all other 
interventions in our network meta-analysis. Infliximab 
ranked second for both outcomes. Regarding safety, 
vedolizumab was still ranked as the safest drug in 
terms of adverse events and serious adverse events, as 
previously 
observed

pro1: Ustekinumab is an anti-interleukin-12/23 antibody and has been ranked highest in patients with prior exposure to TNF antagonists, such as infliximab. It is effective for induction of remission and endoscopic improvement. It may be a good choice for patients who have developed antibodies to anti-TNF agents, leading to loss of response.
cons1: Ustekinumab may have limited efficacy in some patients, and there is a risk of primary non-response or secondary loss of response. There is also a risk of immunogenicity, similar to other biologics.
pro2: Tofacitinib is a Janus kinase inhibitor and has also been ranked highest in patients with prior exposure to TNF antagonists. It is effective for induction of remission and endoscopic improvement. As a small molecule, it is less likely to provoke an immune response leading to the formation of antibodies, which can limit the effectiveness of the drug.
cons2: Tofacitinib may have limited efficacy in some patients, and there is a risk of primary non-response or secondary loss of response. There are also potential side effects to consider, including an increased risk of infections.

source5:
title: First- and Second-Line Pharmacotherapies for Patients With Moderate to Severely Active Ulcerative Colitis: An Updated Network Meta-Analysis

filename: PIIS1542356520300446.pdf

page: 1

text: What You Need to Know
Background
A systematic review and network meta-analysis is
needed to compare efﬁcacy and safety of ﬁrst-line
(biologic-naïve) and second-line (prior exposure to
tumor necrosis factor [TNF] antagonists) agents for
treatment of moderate to severely active ulcerative
colitis.
Findings
Inﬂiximab was ranked highest in biologic-naïve pa-
tients, and ustekinumab and tofacitinib were ranked
highest in patients with prior exposure to TNF an-
tagonists, for induction of remission and endoscopic
improvement. More trials of direct comparisons are
needed to inform clinical decision-making with
greater conﬁdence.
Implications for patient care
Patients with moderate to severely active ulcerative
colitis should receive inﬂiximab or vedolizumab as
ﬁrst-line therapy, or ustekinumab or tofacitinib if
they have prior exposure to TNF antagonists.
2180 Singh et al

of infections (SUCRA, 0.81), followed by ustekinumab (SUCRA, 0.63) in maintenance trials.
CONCLUSIONS:
In a systematic review and network meta-analysis, we found inﬂiximab to be ranked highest in
biologic-naïve patients, and ustekinumab and tofacitinib were ranked highest in patients with
prior exposure to TNF antagonists, for induction of remission and endoscopic improvement in
patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. More trials of direct comparisons are
needed to inform clinical decision making with greater conﬁdence.

text: (prior exposure to tumor necrosis factor [TNF] antagonists) agents for treatment of moder-
ate to severely active ulcerative colitis in a systematic review and network meta-analysis.
METHODS:
We searched publication databases through September 30, 2019, for randomized trials of
adults with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis treated with TNF antagonists, vedolizumab,
tofacitinib, or ustekinumab, as ﬁrst-line or second-line agents, compared with placebo or
another active agent. Efﬁcacy outcomes were induction and maintenance of remission and
endoscopic improvement; safety outcomes were serious adverse events and infections. We
performed a ﬁxed-effects network meta-analysis using the frequentist approach, and calculated
odds ratios (ORs) and 95% CI values. Agents were ranked using surface under the cumulative
ranking (SUCRA) probabilities. Overall quality of evidence was rated using GRADE (Grading of
Recommendations, Assessment, Development and Evaluation).

pro1: Infliximab is a TNF-alpha inhibitor that has been shown to be effective in treating both ulcerative colitis and rheumatoid arthritis. It can lead to increased rates of mucosal healing, deep remission, and corticosteroid-free remission, improving the quality of life for patients.
cons1: Infliximab can have serious side effects, including increased risk of infections. It can also cause infusion reactions and there is a risk of developing antibodies to the drug, which can decrease its effectiveness over time.
pro2: Adalimumab is another TNF-alpha inhibitor that can be used to treat both ulcerative colitis and rheumatoid arthritis. It is administered via subcutaneous injection, which may be more convenient for some patients compared to infliximab's intravenous administration.
cons2: Adalimumab can also have serious side effects, including increased risk of infections. Some patients may experience injection site reactions. As with infliximab, there is a risk of developing antibodies to the drug, which can decrease its effectiveness over time.

INTRODUCTION 
  Ulcerative colitis (UC) is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the bowel that causes 
continuous mucosal inflammation commencing in the rectum and extending proximally for a 
variable extent.[1] It is estimated that UC affects 2.5 million people in Europe,[2] and the 
disease follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent flares of disease activity, 
some of which may be moderate to severe. Management of these is medical, for the most 
part, with surgery reserved for patients with refractory disease. Although 5-aminosalicylates 
(5-ASAs) are efficacious for mild to moderate disease activity,[3-6] more severe flares are 
usually treated with corticosteroids.[7] However, these have potentially serious adverse 
effects and a substantial proportion of patients may become either dependent on them to 
maintain remission,[8] or refractory to them.[9] As a result, over the last 20 years novel

Human: PATIENT PROFILE: question
pro1: Adalimumab is a self-administered subcutaneous injection which can be done at home, providing convenience and limiting time spent in hospital. It is an anti-TNF agent that has been shown to be effective in controlling disease activity, increasing rates of mucosal healing, deep remission, and corticosteroid-free remission, and improving quality of life in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis.
cons1: Adalimumab requires regular self-injections, which some patients may find uncomfortable or inconvenient. As with all biologics, there is a risk of serious infections and other side effects. It may also not work for everyone, and some patients may develop antibodies to the drug, reducing its effectiveness over time.
pro2: Upadacitinib is an oral medication, which may be more convenient for some patients compared to injections or infusions. It has been suggested to be potentially more efficacious than other advanced therapies at achieving clinical response, clinical remission, and endoscopic response over 1 year for moderately to severely active ulcerative colitis patients.
cons2: As a newer drug, long-term safety data for upadacitinib may not be as robust as for older biologics. Side effects can include serious infections, increased cholesterol levels, and potential liver damage. It may also not work for everyone, and some patients may develop resistance to the drug over time.

Human: PATIENT PROFILE: question
pro1: Tofacitinib has been ranked highly in patients with prior exposure to TNF antagonists, indicating it may be effective in patients who have not responded to these treatments. It is also an oral medication, which may be more convenient for some patients compared to injectable or intravenous treatments.
cons1: Tofacitinib may have a higher risk of serious infections compared to other treatments. It may also not be as effective in inducing remission and endoscopic improvement as other treatments.
pro2: Upadacitinib has been shown to be effective in inducing clinical remission and response in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis, including those who have had prior exposure to anti-TNF therapies.
cons2: The safety profile of upadacitinib is not fully known, and it may have a higher risk of serious infections compared to other treatments. It is also a newer drug, so long-term data on its effectiveness and safety are not yet available.

title: First- and Second-Line Pharmacotherapies for Patients With Moderate to Severely Active Ulcerative Colitis: An Updated Network Meta-Analysis

filename: PIIS1542356520300446.pdf

page: 0

text: (prior exposure to tumor necrosis factor [TNF] antagonists) agents for treatment of moder-
ate to severely active ulcerative colitis in a systematic review and network meta-analysis.
METHODS:
We searched publication databases through September 30, 2019, for randomized trials of
adults with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis treated with TNF antagonists, vedolizumab,
tofacitinib, or ustekinumab, as ﬁrst-line or second-line agents, compared with placebo or
another active agent. Efﬁcacy outcomes were induction and maintenance of remission and
endoscopic improvement; safety outcomes were serious adverse events and infections. We
performed a ﬁxed-effects network meta-analysis using the frequentist approach, and calculated
odds ratios (ORs) and 95% CI values. Agents were ranked using surface under the cumulative
ranking (SUCRA) probabilities. Overall quality of evidence was rated using GRADE (Grading of
Recommendations, Assessment, Development and Evaluation).

text: Burr et al. 
 
5 of 45 
STUDY HIGHLIGHTS 
 
What is already known about this subject 
• Ulcerative colitis (UC) follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent 
flares of disease activity, some of which may be moderate to severe. 
• These are usually treated with corticosteroids, which have potentially serious adverse 
effects, so biological therapies and small molecules have been developed and licensed 
for this indication.  
• Although previous network meta-analyses have compared their efficacy and safety, 
this is a rapidly moving field, and there are already several newer drugs that have 
shown efficacy in phase III clinical trials that were not considered in these. 
 
What are the new findings 
• In terms of clinical remission and clinical response, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked 
first in all patients, in patients previously exposed to anti-tumour necrosis factor 
(TNF)-α therapies, and in patients naïve to these drugs.
source7:
title: First- and Second-Line Pharmacotherapies for Patients With Moderate to Severely Active Ulcerative Colitis: An Updated Network Meta-Analysis

filename: PIIS1542356520300446.pdf

page: 1

text: What You Need to Know
Background
A systematic review and network meta-analysis is
needed to compare efﬁcacy and safety of ﬁrst-line
(biologic-naïve) and second-line (prior exposure to
tumor necrosis factor [TNF] antagonists) agents for
treatment of moderate to severely active ulcerative
colitis.
Findings
Inﬂiximab was ranked highest in biologic-naïve pa-
tients, and ustekinumab and tofacitinib were ranked
highest in patients with prior exposure to TNF an-
tagonists, for induction of remission and endoscopic
improvement. More trials of direct comparisons are
needed to inform clinical decision-making with
greater conﬁdence.
Implications for patient care
Patients with moderate to severely active ulcerative
colitis should receive inﬂiximab or vedolizumab as
ﬁrst-line therapy, or ustekinumab or tofacitinib if
they have prior exposure to TNF antagonists.
2180 Singh et al

text: vs adalimumab: OR, 11.05; 95% CI, 1.79–68.41; moderate CE). Vedolizumab had the lowest risk
of infections (SUCRA, 0.81), followed by ustekinumab (SUCRA, 0.63) in maintenance trials.
CONCLUSIONS:
In a systematic review and network meta-analysis, we found inﬂiximab to be ranked highest in
biologic-naïve patients, and ustekinumab and tofacitinib were ranked highest in patients with
prior exposure to TNF antagonists, for induction of remission and endoscopic improvement in
patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. More trials of direct comparisons are
needed to inform clinical decision making with greater conﬁdence.

Human: PATIENT PROFILE: question
pro1: Upadacitinib has been shown to rank first in terms of clinical remission and response in all patients, including those previously exposed to anti-tumour necrosis factor (TNF)-α therapies, and in patients naïve to these drugs. This suggests that it could be effective for a patient with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis.
cons1: The potential side effects of Upadacitinib are not mentioned in the provided context. However, common side effects of this drug can include upper respiratory tract infections, nausea, cough, and fever. It may also increase the risk of serious infections, malignancies, and thrombosis.
pro2: TNF inhibitors are recommended for patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis and can also be effective in treating spondylarthritis, an extraintestinal manifestation of UC. They have revolutionised therapeutics for ulcerative colitis, enabling better disease control in terms of increasing the rates of mucosal healing, deep remission, and corticosteroid-free remission, and improving quality of life.
cons2: Treatment with TNF inhibitors has several limitations, including limited efficacy, primary non-response, secondary loss of response, and immunogenicity. They can also have potentially serious side effects, including increased risk of infections and malignancies.

title: Efficacy of biological therapies and small molecules in moderate to severe ulcerative colitis: systematic review and network meta-analysis

filename: gutjnl-2021-326390R2 CLEAN.pdf

page: 5

text: Burr et al. 
 
5 of 45 
STUDY HIGHLIGHTS 
 
What is already known about this subject 
• Ulcerative colitis (UC) follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent 
flares of disease activity, some of which may be moderate to severe. 
• These are usually treated with corticosteroids, which have potentially serious adverse 
effects, so biological therapies and small molecules have been developed and licensed 
for this indication.  
• Although previous network meta-analyses have compared their efficacy and safety, 
this is a rapidly moving field, and there are already several newer drugs that have 
shown efficacy in phase III clinical trials that were not considered in these. 
 
What are the new findings 
• In terms of clinical remission and clinical response, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked 
first in all patients, in patients previously exposed to anti-tumour necrosis factor 
(TNF)-α therapies, and in patients naïve to these drugs.

Human: PATIENT PROFILE: question
pro1: Upadacitinib has been shown to be highly efficacious in inducing clinical remission and response in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis, including those who have previously been exposed to anti-TNF therapies or are naïve to these drugs. It may be a suitable option for this patient who is not responding to azathioprine.
cons1: While upadacitinib has shown promising results, it is a relatively new drug and long-term safety data may not be as robust as for other, more established treatments. Potential side effects include infections, increased cholesterol levels, and liver enzyme elevations.
pro2: Vedolizumab is a biologic therapy that has been approved for the treatment of moderate-to-severe ulcerative colitis. It works by blocking the movement of white blood cells into the gut, reducing inflammation. It may be a suitable option for this patient who is not responding to azathioprine.
cons2: While vedolizumab is generally well-tolerated, potential side effects can include headache, joint pain, nausea, and fever. In rare cases, it can cause serious infections. Additionally, it may take several weeks to months to see an effect.

INTRODUCTION 
  Ulcerative colitis (UC) is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the bowel that causes 
continuous mucosal inflammation commencing in the rectum and extending proximally for a 
variable extent.[1] It is estimated that UC affects 2.5 million people in Europe,[2] and the 
disease follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent flares of disease activity, 
some of which may be moderate to severe. Management of these is medical, for the most 
part, with surgery reserved for patients with refractory disease. Although 5-aminosalicylates 
(5-ASAs) are efficacious for mild to moderate disease activity,[3-6] more severe flares are 
usually treated with corticosteroids.[7] However, these have potentially serious adverse 
effects and a substantial proportion of patients may become either dependent on them to 
maintain remission,[8] or refractory to them.[9] As a result, over the last 20 years novel

Ulcerative colitis is a chronic, idiopathic, potentially 
disabling condition that is clinically characterised 
by bloody diarrhoea, abdominal pain, and tenesmus.1 
Ulcerative colitis most commonly presents during the 
third and fifth decades of life, and is associated with an 
impaired health-related quality of life and considerable 
economic burden.2,3
Nearly 20 years ago, the advent of anti-tumour necrosis 
factor biologics (eg, infliximab, adalimumab, and 
golimumab) revolutionised therapeutics for ulcerative

increasing the rates of mucosal healing, deep remission, 
and corticosteroid-free remission, and improving quality 
of life. Biologics with other targets were later approved 
for the treatment of moderate-to-severe ulcerative colitis,

pro1: Infliximab has been evaluated in a large, dedicated placebo-randomized trial for fistula treatment, showing good results. It is also part of the anti-TNF agents that revolutionized therapeutics for ulcerative colitis, enabling better disease control in terms of increasing the rates of mucosal healing, deep remission, and corticosteroid-free remission, and improving quality of life.
cons1: Infliximab, like other biologics, can have side effects including risk of infections, allergic reactions, and potential development of antibodies against the drug, which can decrease its effectiveness over time.
pro2: Adalimumab is another anti-TNF agent that has shown efficacy in the treatment of ulcerative colitis, including severe cases. It can lead to increased rates of mucosal healing, deep remission, and corticosteroid-free remission, and improved quality of life.
cons2: Adalimumab can have side effects similar to other anti-TNF agents, including risk of infections, allergic reactions, and potential development of antibodies against the drug, which can decrease its effectiveness over time.

filename: gutjnl-2021-326390R2 CLEAN.pdf

page: 5

text: Burr et al. 
 
5 of 45 
STUDY HIGHLIGHTS 
 
What is already known about this subject 
• Ulcerative colitis (UC) follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent 
flares of disease activity, some of which may be moderate to severe. 
• These are usually treated with corticosteroids, which have potentially serious adverse 
effects, so biological therapies and small molecules have been developed and licensed 
for this indication.  
• Although previous network meta-analyses have compared their efficacy and safety, 
this is a rapidly moving field, and there are already several newer drugs that have 
shown efficacy in phase III clinical trials that were not considered in these. 
 
What are the new findings 
• In terms of clinical remission and clinical response, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked 
first in all patients, in patients previously exposed to anti-tumour necrosis factor 
(TNF)-α therapies, and in patients naïve to these drugs.

Human: PATIENT PROFILE: question
pro1: Vedolizumab is a gut-selective immunosuppressant, which means it specifically targets the gut and spares other organs. This makes it a safer option for patients with liver disease like primary sclerosing cholangitis and decompensated cirrhosis. It is also effective in treating moderate to severe ulcerative colitis.
cons1: The main disadvantage of Vedolizumab is that it may take longer to work compared to other treatments. It also requires intravenous administration, which can be inconvenient for some patients.
pro2: Ustekinumab is effective in treating moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It works by blocking certain proteins that cause inflammation, which can help reduce symptoms and prevent flare-ups.
cons2: Ustekinumab may not be suitable for patients with liver disease as it can potentially cause or worsen liver problems. It also requires subcutaneous or intravenous administration, which can be inconvenient for some patients. Additionally, it may increase the risk of infections.

behavior was associated with a higher risk of progression to
perianal disease (HR, 5.65; 95% CI, 2.65–12.03) and was a
risk factor for resection (HR, 3.92; 95% CI, 1.86–8.67) and

prompt:
System: 
You are a physician assistant giving advice on treatment for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis (UC).
Make reference to the CONTEXT given to assess the scenario.
If the answer cannot be inferred from CONTEXT, return "NO ANSWER", don't try to make up an answer.
=================================
TASK: ANALYSE the given patient profile based on given query based on one of the following criteria:
- Whether treated patient is new patient or patient under maintenance
- Prior response to Infliximab
- Prior failure to Anti-TNF agents
- Prior failure to Vedolizumab
- Age
- Pregnancy
- Extraintestinale manifestations
- Pouchitis

FINALLY RETURN up to 2 TOP choices of biological drugs given patient profile and context. Explain the PROS and CONS of the 2 choices.
If answer cannot be derived from context, RETURN "NO ANSWER" and explain reason.
=================================
OUTPUT INSTRUCTIONS:
Output your answer as a list of JSON objects with keys: drug_name, advantages, disadvantages.
=================================
CONTEXT:
summaries
=================================

Human: PATIENT PROFILE: question
pro1: Upadacitinib has been shown to be highly efficacious in inducing clinical remission and response in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It has been ranked first in terms of clinical remission and response, even in patients previously exposed to anti-TNF-α therapies. This suggests that it could provide a rapid response to treatment, which is a priority for the patient.
cons1: While Upadacitinib has shown promising results, it is a relatively new drug and long-term safety data may not be as robust as for other, more established treatments. As with any medication, there is also the potential for side effects, which can include infections, changes in blood counts, and liver problems.
pro2: Infliximab is a well-established treatment for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis and has been shown to increase rates of mucosal healing, deep remission, and corticosteroid-free remission. This could potentially provide the rapid response to treatment that the patient is seeking.
cons2: Infliximab is administered via intravenous infusion, which may be less convenient for some patients compared to oral medications. There is also the potential for side effects, including infections, allergic reactions, and liver problems. Additionally, some patients may develop antibodies to Infliximab, which can reduce its effectiveness over time.

INTRODUCTION 
  Ulcerative colitis (UC) is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the bowel that causes 
continuous mucosal inflammation commencing in the rectum and extending proximally for a 
variable extent.[1] It is estimated that UC affects 2.5 million people in Europe,[2] and the 
disease follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent flares of disease activity, 
some of which may be moderate to severe. Management of these is medical, for the most 
part, with surgery reserved for patients with refractory disease. Although 5-aminosalicylates 
(5-ASAs) are efficacious for mild to moderate disease activity,[3-6] more severe flares are 
usually treated with corticosteroids.[7] However, these have potentially serious adverse 
effects and a substantial proportion of patients may become either dependent on them to 
maintain remission,[8] or refractory to them.[9] As a result, over the last 20 years novel

text: Burr et al. 
 
5 of 45 
STUDY HIGHLIGHTS 
 
What is already known about this subject 
• Ulcerative colitis (UC) follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent 
flares of disease activity, some of which may be moderate to severe. 
• These are usually treated with corticosteroids, which have potentially serious adverse 
effects, so biological therapies and small molecules have been developed and licensed 
for this indication.  
• Although previous network meta-analyses have compared their efficacy and safety, 
this is a rapidly moving field, and there are already several newer drugs that have 
shown efficacy in phase III clinical trials that were not considered in these. 
 
What are the new findings 
• In terms of clinical remission and clinical response, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked 
first in all patients, in patients previously exposed to anti-tumour necrosis factor 
(TNF)-α therapies, and in patients naïve to these drugs.

text: (prior exposure to tumor necrosis factor [TNF] antagonists) agents for treatment of moder-
ate to severely active ulcerative colitis in a systematic review and network meta-analysis.
METHODS:
We searched publication databases through September 30, 2019, for randomized trials of
adults with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis treated with TNF antagonists, vedolizumab,
tofacitinib, or ustekinumab, as ﬁrst-line or second-line agents, compared with placebo or
another active agent. Efﬁcacy outcomes were induction and maintenance of remission and
endoscopic improvement; safety outcomes were serious adverse events and infections. We
performed a ﬁxed-effects network meta-analysis using the frequentist approach, and calculated
odds ratios (ORs) and 95% CI values. Agents were ranked using surface under the cumulative
ranking (SUCRA) probabilities. Overall quality of evidence was rated using GRADE (Grading of
Recommendations, Assessment, Development and Evaluation).

source9:
title: First- and Second-Line Pharmacotherapies for Patients With Moderate to Severely Active Ulcerative Colitis: An Updated Network Meta-Analysis

filename: PIIS1542356520300446.pdf

page: 1

text: What You Need to Know
Background
A systematic review and network meta-analysis is
needed to compare efﬁcacy and safety of ﬁrst-line
(biologic-naïve) and second-line (prior exposure to
tumor necrosis factor [TNF] antagonists) agents for
treatment of moderate to severely active ulcerative
colitis.
Findings
Inﬂiximab was ranked highest in biologic-naïve pa-
tients, and ustekinumab and tofacitinib were ranked
highest in patients with prior exposure to TNF an-
tagonists, for induction of remission and endoscopic
improvement. More trials of direct comparisons are
needed to inform clinical decision-making with
greater conﬁdence.
Implications for patient care
Patients with moderate to severely active ulcerative
colitis should receive inﬂiximab or vedolizumab as
ﬁrst-line therapy, or ustekinumab or tofacitinib if
they have prior exposure to TNF antagonists.
2180 Singh et al

Human: PATIENT PROFILE: question
pro1: Infliximab is a TNF-alpha inhibitor that has been shown to be effective in treating both ulcerative colitis and extraintestinal manifestations such as pyoderma gangrenosum. It can lead to increased rates of mucosal healing, deep remission, and corticosteroid-free remission, thus improving the quality of life.
cons1: Infliximab can have potential side effects including risk of infections, lymphoma, and other malignancies. It may also cause infusion reactions and there is a risk of developing antibodies to the drug, which can decrease its effectiveness over time.
pro2: Adalimumab is another TNF-alpha inhibitor that can be effective in treating moderate to severe ulcerative colitis and extraintestinal manifestations. It is administered subcutaneously, which may be more convenient for some patients compared to infliximab which is given via infusion.
cons2: Adalimumab also carries risks of serious infections, malignancies, and may cause injection site reactions. As with infliximab, there is a risk of developing antibodies to the drug, which can decrease its effectiveness over time.

INTRODUCTION 
  Ulcerative colitis (UC) is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the bowel that causes 
continuous mucosal inflammation commencing in the rectum and extending proximally for a 
variable extent.[1] It is estimated that UC affects 2.5 million people in Europe,[2] and the 
disease follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent flares of disease activity, 
some of which may be moderate to severe. Management of these is medical, for the most 
part, with surgery reserved for patients with refractory disease. Although 5-aminosalicylates 
(5-ASAs) are efficacious for mild to moderate disease activity,[3-6] more severe flares are 
usually treated with corticosteroids.[7] However, these have potentially serious adverse 
effects and a substantial proportion of patients may become either dependent on them to 
maintain remission,[8] or refractory to them.[9] As a result, over the last 20 years novel

matory Bowel Disease and the American Gastroenterological

groups based on phenotype and other characteristics.59,60
In CD, the presence of large or deep mucosal lesions on
endoscopy or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), history of
a ﬁstula, abscess, or intestinal resection are predictors of
worse outcomes.59,60 In a prospective population-based
inception cohort of 213 patients with CD, penetrating
behavior was associated with a higher risk of progression to
perianal disease (HR, 5.65; 95% CI, 2.65–12.03) and was a
risk factor for resection (HR, 3.92; 95% CI, 1.86–8.67) and
hospitalization (HR, 1.01; 95% CI, 1.00–1.01).16 Ileal and
upper gastrointestinal disease location and extensive dis-

Human: PATIENT PROFILE: question
pro1: Vedolizumab is a gut-selective biologic, meaning it specifically targets the gut and does not have systemic effects. This makes it a safer option for patients with extraintestinal manifestations such as optic neuritis. It has been approved for the treatment of moderate-to-severe ulcerative colitis and has shown efficacy in inducing and maintaining remission.
cons1: Vedolizumab may have limited efficacy in some patients, and there can be primary non-response or secondary loss of response. It also requires intravenous administration, which may not be convenient for all patients.
pro2: Ustekinumab is a biologic that targets interleukin-12 and interleukin-23, key drivers of immune-mediated inflammatory diseases. It has been approved for the treatment of moderate-to-severe ulcerative colitis. It may be a good option for patients who have not responded to or cannot tolerate other treatments.
cons2: Ustekinumab may not work for everyone, and some patients may experience side effects. It also requires initial intravenous administration followed by subcutaneous injections, which may not be preferred by some patients.

text: Burr et al. 
 
5 of 45 
STUDY HIGHLIGHTS 
 
What is already known about this subject 
• Ulcerative colitis (UC) follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent 
flares of disease activity, some of which may be moderate to severe. 
• These are usually treated with corticosteroids, which have potentially serious adverse 
effects, so biological therapies and small molecules have been developed and licensed 
for this indication.  
• Although previous network meta-analyses have compared their efficacy and safety, 
this is a rapidly moving field, and there are already several newer drugs that have 
shown efficacy in phase III clinical trials that were not considered in these. 
 
What are the new findings 
• In terms of clinical remission and clinical response, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked 
first in all patients, in patients previously exposed to anti-tumour necrosis factor 
(TNF)-α therapies, and in patients naïve to these drugs.

pro1: Infliximab is a type of anti-tumor necrosis factor (anti-TNF) biologic that has revolutionized therapeutics for ulcerative colitis. It has been shown to increase rates of mucosal healing, deep remission, and corticosteroid-free remission, thereby improving the quality of life for patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis.
cons1: Infliximab, like other anti-TNF agents, can have side effects including increased risk of infections, potential for allergic reactions, and may not be effective in all patients. It is also administered via intravenous infusion, which may be inconvenient for some patients.
pro2: Adalimumab is another anti-TNF biologic that can be used in the treatment of moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It can help control disease symptoms, promote mucosal healing, and improve quality of life.
cons2: Adalimumab can have side effects similar to infliximab, including increased risk of infections and potential for allergic reactions. It may also not be effective in all patients. Unlike infliximab, adalimumab is administered via subcutaneous injection, which some patients may find uncomfortable.

text: Disease Phenotype and Clinical Characteristics
The International Organization for the Study of Inﬂam-
matory Bowel Disease and the American Gastroenterological
Association (AGA) provide a framework for categorization of
CD and UC severity into mild-, moderate-, and high-risk
groups based on phenotype and other characteristics.59,60
In CD, the presence of large or deep mucosal lesions on
endoscopy or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), history of
a ﬁstula, abscess, or intestinal resection are predictors of
worse outcomes.59,60 In a prospective population-based
inception cohort of 213 patients with CD, penetrating
behavior was associated with a higher risk of progression to
perianal disease (HR, 5.65; 95% CI, 2.65–12.03) and was a
risk factor for resection (HR, 3.92; 95% CI, 1.86–8.67) and
hospitalization (HR, 1.01; 95% CI, 1.00–1.01).16 Ileal and
upper gastrointestinal disease location and extensive dis-
ease are also markers of severe disease.61 Cigarette smoking

is associated with complications and need for therapy
escalation.61
In CD, the threshold of suspicion should be low for high-
quality imaging of the pelvis, such as MRI, to rule our
perianal CD. In a retrospective study of 136 pediatric CD
patients, presence of anal ﬁssures and skin tags, non-White
race, and elevated C-reactive protein (CRP) were risk factors
for perianal CD.62 In another study of 274 patients in China
with recently diagnosed CD, all of whom underwent MRI
pelvis, asymptomatic perianal ﬁstulas were diagnosed in
17.5% of patients and colonic location of CD was a risk
factor for asymptomatic perianal ﬁstulas.63
In UC, corresponding predictors of aggressive disease
advised by the International Organization for the Study of
Inﬂammatory Bowel Disease include active colonic ulcers

Human: PATIENT PROFILE: question
pro1: Upadacitinib has been shown to be highly efficacious in inducing clinical remission and response in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It is also available in an oral formulation, which may be preferred by patients who are averse to injections or infusions.
cons1: While Upadacitinib has shown promising results, it is a relatively new drug and long-term safety data may not be as robust as for other, more established treatments. Side effects can include infections, nausea, and acne.
pro2: Tofacitinib is another oral medication that has been shown to be effective in treating moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It has a longer track record than Upadacitinib, which may provide more confidence in its safety profile.
cons2: Tofacitinib can have side effects including increased cholesterol levels, increased risk of infection, and potential increased risk of blood clots. It may also be less effective than Upadacitinib in inducing remission.

text: Burr et al. 
 
5 of 45 
STUDY HIGHLIGHTS 
 
What is already known about this subject 
• Ulcerative colitis (UC) follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent 
flares of disease activity, some of which may be moderate to severe. 
• These are usually treated with corticosteroids, which have potentially serious adverse 
effects, so biological therapies and small molecules have been developed and licensed 
for this indication.  
• Although previous network meta-analyses have compared their efficacy and safety, 
this is a rapidly moving field, and there are already several newer drugs that have 
shown efficacy in phase III clinical trials that were not considered in these. 
 
What are the new findings 
• In terms of clinical remission and clinical response, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked 
first in all patients, in patients previously exposed to anti-tumour necrosis factor 
(TNF)-α therapies, and in patients naïve to these drugs.

text: Burr et al. 
 
5 of 45 
STUDY HIGHLIGHTS 
 
What is already known about this subject 
• Ulcerative colitis (UC) follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent 
flares of disease activity, some of which may be moderate to severe. 
• These are usually treated with corticosteroids, which have potentially serious adverse 
effects, so biological therapies and small molecules have been developed and licensed 
for this indication.  
• Although previous network meta-analyses have compared their efficacy and safety, 
this is a rapidly moving field, and there are already several newer drugs that have 
shown efficacy in phase III clinical trials that were not considered in these. 
 
What are the new findings 
• In terms of clinical remission and clinical response, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked 
first in all patients, in patients previously exposed to anti-tumour necrosis factor 
(TNF)-α therapies, and in patients naïve to these drugs.

question: 38 year-old woman with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis and pulmonary tuberculosis which was treated 2 years ago.
gt_reason: Anti-TNFs and JAK inhs have associations/concerns with infections
prompt:
System: 
You are a physician assistant giving advice on treatment for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis (UC).
Make reference to the CONTEXT given to assess the scenario.
If the answer cannot be inferred from CONTEXT, return "NO ANSWER", don't try to make up an answer.
=================================
TASK: ANALYSE the given patient profile based on given query based on one of the following criteria:
- Whether treated patient is new patient or patient under maintenance
- Prior response to Infliximab
- Prior failure to Anti-TNF agents
- Prior failure to Vedolizumab
- Age
- Pregnancy
- Extraintestinale manifestations
- Pouchitis

FINALLY RETURN up to 2 TOP choices of biological drugs given patient profile and context. Explain the PROS and CONS of the 2 choices.
If answer cannot be derived from context, RETURN "NO ANSWER" and explain reason.
=================================
OUTPUT INSTRUCTIONS:
Output your answer as a list of JSON objects with keys: drug_name, advantages, disadvantages.
=================================
CONTEXT:
summaries
=================================

Human: PATIENT PROFILE: question
pro1: Vedolizumab is a gut-selective immunosuppressant, meaning it specifically targets the gut and has less systemic side effects. This makes it a safer option for patients with a history of tuberculosis as it is less likely to reactivate latent infections compared to other systemic immunosuppressants.
cons1: Vedolizumab may take longer to show effects compared to other treatments. It also requires intravenous administration, which might not be convenient for all patients.
pro2: Ustekinumab is another option that has been shown to be effective in treating moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It works by inhibiting interleukin-12 and interleukin-23, which are involved in the inflammatory process.
cons2: Ustekinumab may increase the risk of infections, including the reactivation of tuberculosis. Therefore, it should be used with caution in patients with a history of tuberculosis. It also requires subcutaneous or intravenous administration, which might not be convenient for all patients.

  Ulcerative colitis (UC) is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the bowel that causes 
continuous mucosal inflammation commencing in the rectum and extending proximally for a 
variable extent.[1] It is estimated that UC affects 2.5 million people in Europe,[2] and the

part, with surgery reserved for patients with refractory disease. Although 5-aminosalicylates 
(5-ASAs) are efficacious for mild to moderate disease activity,[3-6] more severe flares are 
usually treated with corticosteroids.[7] However, these have potentially serious adverse 
effects and a substantial proportion of patients may become either dependent on them to 
maintain remission,[8] or refractory to them.[9] As a result, over the last 20 years novel

text: SYSTEMATIC REVIEWS AND META-ANALYSES
Siddharth Singh, Section Editor
First- and Second-Line Pharmacotherapies for Patients With
Moderate to Severely Active Ulcerative Colitis: An Updated
Network Meta-Analysis
Siddharth Singh,*,‡ Mohammad Hassan Murad,§ Mathurin Fumery,j
Parambir S. Dulai,* and William J. Sandborn*
*Division of Gastroenterology, ‡Division of Biomedical Informatics, University of California San Diego, La Jolla, California;
§Robert D and Patricia E Kern Center for the Science of Health Care Delivery, Mayo Clinic, Rochester, Minnesota;
||Gastroenterology Unit, Peritox UMR I-0I, Amiens University and Hospital, Université de Picardie Jules Verne, Amiens, France
BACKGROUND & AIMS:
We compared the efﬁcacy and safety of different ﬁrst-line (biologic-naïve) and second-line
(prior exposure to tumor necrosis factor [TNF] antagonists) agents for treatment of moder-
ate to severely active ulcerative colitis in a systematic review and network meta-analysis.
METHODS:
source10:
title: First- and Second-Line Pharmacotherapies for Patients With Moderate to Severely Active Ulcerative Colitis: An Updated Network Meta-Analysis

filename: PIIS1542356520300446.pdf

page: 0

text: (prior exposure to tumor necrosis factor [TNF] antagonists) agents for treatment of moder-
ate to severely active ulcerative colitis in a systematic review and network meta-analysis.
METHODS:
We searched publication databases through September 30, 2019, for randomized trials of
adults with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis treated with TNF antagonists, vedolizumab,
tofacitinib, or ustekinumab, as ﬁrst-line or second-line agents, compared with placebo or
another active agent. Efﬁcacy outcomes were induction and maintenance of remission and
endoscopic improvement; safety outcomes were serious adverse events and infections. We
performed a ﬁxed-effects network meta-analysis using the frequentist approach, and calculated
odds ratios (ORs) and 95% CI values. Agents were ranked using surface under the cumulative
ranking (SUCRA) probabilities. Overall quality of evidence was rated using GRADE (Grading of
Recommendations, Assessment, Development and Evaluation).
RESULTS:
